39500.comment:
For Consideration.
I emphatically support the proposed three-year lease extension for all existing cottage leased lots in Rondeau Provincial Park, as described in ERO Policy Proposal 019-0907.
This new lease extension should be granted automatically to all existing leaseholders. This three year time period should be used to reach a permanent solution that will ensure the cottage community remains forever within Rondeau Park. When a permanent solution is reached prior to the three-year deadline, I support it being implemented as soon as possible.
Rondeau Park's founding charter included the presence of cottages.
The Rondeau cottage community has co-existed within the Park's ecosystem for over a century. Members of Rondeau's cottage community share an equal sense of stewardship and responsibility for preserving its unique environmental, historic and cultural treasures as any other Friend of Rondeau.
Rondeau has proven to be a model of how a Provincial Park of national significance can thrive, while balancing conservation, preservation and recreation.
Thank you.

39501.comment: Yes! I support the three-year lease extension as described in ERO Policy Proposal 019-0907. This new lease extension should be granted automatically to all leaseholders. This time should be used to reach a permanent solution that will ensure the cottage community remains forever. If a permanent solution is reached prior to the three-year deadline, I support it being implemented as soon as possible.

39502.comment: "I support the continuation of the Rondeau cottage community in perpetuity. I support the three-year lease extension as described in ERO Policy Proposal 019-0907. This lease extension should be granted automatically to all leaseholders. This time should be used to reach a permanent solution that will ensure the cottage community remains forever.  If a permanent solution is reached prior to the three-year deadline, I support it being implemented as soon as possible."

39505.comment:
In support of ERO 019-0907.
Please proceed with temporary lease extension in order to arrive at a long term permanent solution for the occupation of cottage lots within Rondeau Provincial Park.
When considering the number of Ontario provincial parks and conservation areas, and the occupation rates overall it is quite apparent that the original decision made in the 1950's to eliminate cottages from Rondeau Park is no longer applicable. In reality, that decision has not made any sense for the past 25 years.
In addition, the fact that the 'footprint' of cottage lots represents less than 2% of the overall area of Rondeau Park, the environmental impact of cottages is immeasurable particularly when compared to the overall negative impact of campers and day users on the Park.

39601.comment:
I support ERO 019-0907 and the proposed lease extension of heritage cottages in Rondeau Provincial Park.
Since 1894, when lots were first surveyed, cottaging has been a part of the Rondeau Park community. The cottagers take great pride in the park, actively promoting the betterment of the park, protecting, preserving and promoting Rondeau’s natural and historical environment. I support the continuation of the Rondeau Cottage Community, they are excellent stewards of the park.
Thank you

39802.comment:
For Consideration.
I emphatically support the proposed three-year lease extension for all existing cottage leased lots in Rondeau Provincial Park, as described in ERO Policy Proposal 019-0907.
This new lease extension should be granted automatically to all existing leaseholders. This three year time period should be used to reach a permanent solution that will ensure the cottage community remains forever within Rondeau Park. When a permanent solution is reached prior to the three-year deadline, I support it being implemented as soon as possible.
Rondeau Park's founding charter included the presence of cottages.
The Rondeau cottage community has co-existed within the Park's ecosystem for over a century. Members of Rondeau's cottage community share an equal sense of stewardship and responsibility for preserving its unique environmental, historic and cultural treasures as any other Friend of Rondeau.
Rondeau has proven to be a model of how a Provincial Park of national significance can thrive, while balancing conservation, preservation and recreation.
Thank you.

39818.comment:
I am in favour of the ERO 019-907 policiy proposal which gives both parties, the government of Ontario and the cottagers time to work out their differences – as it stands currently the due diligence necesssary on the part of MNRF to achieve a reasonable, measured outcome is yet to be completed. Hence a second extension.
The early history of Rondeau Provincial Park is one that aimed at welcoming people: cottagers, campers, daytrippers, etc. to use and enjoy this special parcel of land, marsh and forest. I am of the opinion that their presence in the park is on the decline. The rising fees for all users. The loss of boating access. The destruction of the public dock. The decline of the observation tower on the Marsh Road. The inadequate recyclling program available in the park. None of these measures are indicative of a Ministry that is invested in encouraging people to make use of what Rondeau has to offer in terms of opportunities for recreatiion, education, and encouraging environmental awarness, biodiversity, and respect for the world we live in. The future of the cottagers is part and parcel of the challenge facing the people of Ontarion to assure a way of life that is in harmony with the natural world. Why can living permanently in Rondeau not be part of a plan to promote a viable, dynamic, use of the natural resources available?
Let us give this proposal a fair shake!

39830.comment:
We support ERO 019-0907.
We look forward to the opportunity for long term/permanent occupation of our cottage lot in Rondeau Provincial Park.
As children we (wife and I) camped with our families in many campgrounds at Provincial Parks throughout Ontario and thoroughly enjoyed our time learning about nature (trees, flowers, birds, other critters,...), walking the trails, swimming where available, and generally enjoying ourselves as most kids do.
As girlfriend/boyfriend we often shared/compared experiences exploring the various Parks and their unique characteristics.
As newlyweds we continued to camp and visit many Parks throughout Ontario and ultimately came across Rondeau Provincial Park and the cottage community in the 1970's. At that time we vowed that someday we too would become cottagers, if at all possible.
It turned out, that just prior to retiring from our respective jobs, we came across an available cottage
in Rondeau that we had seen and fell in love with in the 1970's. We took all of our retirement savings and borrowed money from other family members and proceeded to make our dream come true.
Aside from periods of contentiousness with Ontario Parks over the past 15 years, and the misconceptions that we are "elites" (far from it - just regular working folks that scrimped and saved),
and misunderstandings from distant environmentalists about our treatment of the Park and its natural features. (we love the Park, and spend everyday caring for it when we are there) we truly do want to protect and preserve the Park - including the cottage community.
Who knows - maybe a young family has already spotted our cottage as their retirement dream spot - so  we want to be sure that they too have the opportunity to spend their golden years enjoying cottage life with nature  as we have.
We have faith that a long term solution can be developed for the occupation of cottage lots in Rondeau Provincial Park !!

40010.comment: I approve of ERO 019-0907. There are over 300 Provincial Parks now in Ontario. Rondeau was only the second park established in Ontario just after Algonquin. I support ERO 019-0907

40020.comment:
"I support the three-year lease extension as described in ERO Policy Proposal 019-0907. This new lease extension should be granted automatically to all leaseholders. This time should be used to reach a permanent solution that will ensure the cottage community remains forever. If a permanent solution is reached prior to the three-year deadline, I support it being implemented as soon as possible.”
I was less than a week old for my first visit to my Rondeau cottage. My parents wanted all their children to experience the magic of Rondeau as soon as possible. From that moment, Rondeau has been the one place my family and I can enjoy more than anywhere else in the world. We have travelled to many places around the world and nothing compares to a sunset over Rondeau Bay, a family bbq on our patio, a walk along the lake shore and passing along the beauty and everything that only Rondeau can give from generation to generation (we are 4 generations deep).
Rondeau has gave me my parents (they met at RCY), a place to remind me nothing is more important than family after loss of family members, and a more family dinners than anyone can count.
From the moment I drive into the park see the smiling faces of everyone biking/walking/roller blading by, the drive down Lakeshore Drive watching as the forest grows over the summer, and not even unloading our car until a swim in Lake Erie first. Rondeau is the best place to be!!!
There is no other place I rather be to celebrate my birthday, Father's Day, and Thanksgiving. I cant imagine a season without lessons at RCY, endless days on the beach, trips the visitor centre,  trick or treating at the campgrounds and sharing my love for Rondeau to our next generation.
I cant imagine a summer without Rondeau!

40022.comment:
I support ERO 019-0907.
I support the long term occupation of cottage lots in Rondeau Provincial Park.
Local Chatham-Kent businesses benefit significantly from the cottage community within Rondeau Provincial Park. Many current cottagers continue to defer expenditure for maintenance, repair, and improvements to their cottages while uncertainty continues regarding occupation of cottage lots in Rondeau Provincial Park. This uncertainty must be resolved once and for all. In addition, cottagers contribute to the maintenance expenses of the Park, as well as providing annual Lease Fees to Ontario govt., and Property Taxes to Chatham-Kent. The local economy cannot afford to lose this valuable contributor.

40039.comment:
The Rondeau Cottagers Association (“RCA”) was formed as the Rondeau Park Leaseholders Association in 1928 and represents more than 90% of all cottage owners inside Rondeau Provincial Park. We are recognized by the Province of Ontario as one of three stakeholders in Rondeau, along with Ontario Parks and the Municipality of Chatham-Kent.
The RCA enthusiastically supports ERO 019-0907.  This three-year lease extension should be granted automatically to all leaseholders.  This time period should be used to mutually negotiate a permanent tenure solution that will ensure the cottage community remains forever.  If a permanent solution is reached prior to the three-year deadline, we support it being implemented as soon as possible.
Rondeau Provincial Park was created in May 1894 by the “Rondeau Provincial Park Act”. Under the Act, the park was chartered for the purpose of providing cottaging opportunities for residents of Chatham & Kent County. Sadly the original cottages have all been demolished; the oldest cottages still standing were built around 1900. However their owners keep them in excellent repair and their families continue to enjoy them every summer. Our community has been here since the very beginning; many Rondeau families trace their roots here back many generations.
The Rondeau cottage community has been integrated into the park’s natural environment for over a century. The province has long considered Rondeau as the “Crown Jewel” of diversity in the Ontario Parks system, and it could not be this way if cottages were harming the ecology for the past 125 years. None of the available evidence on our community’s impact on the larger park environment has been any worse than neutral, and several studies have pointed-out a net benefit provided by human habitation structures to shelter species at risk. We believe the permanent continuation of our community offers the least-possible harm to the park’s ecosystem.
We are pleased that Rondeau supports one of the largest concentrations of rare species within a protected area in Ontario, and is home to 132 provincially-significant Species at Risk. We consider them to be our neighbours and our friends, and we believe that such a varied, thriving population can only be indicative of a healthy balance being achieved.  Any claim of long-term environment harm caused by cottagers is simply unsupported by factual data.
The definition of Ecological Integrity leaves-out a significant and arguably relevant line from the Provincial Parks & Conservation Reserves Act (2006) which recognizes the need for “recreational enjoyment” within the definition of Ecological Integrity.  We love this place, and we believe that parks are for people, too.

40052.comment:
I fully support ERO 019-0907.
Chatham-Kent is one of Ontario's economically-depressed areas and it is largely ignored by Queen's Park.  The cottage community in Rondeau Provincial Park is one of the few bright spots in Chatham-Kent, despite the economic instability forced upon the community by the perpetually-expiring cottage leases.  Extending the leases to allow an opportunity for meaningful negotiation on a longer-term solution is a responsible approach that will benefit all parties concerned.
Further, it is not fair to the current leaseholders to drop a (literal) last-minute panic to sign yet another short-term lease extension on New Year's Eve.  All current leaseholders should be granted the extension automatically.  If discussions result in a potential long-term or permanent solution, it should be brought forward for implementation as soon as possible and not delayed until this three-year lease runs out in 2022.
I look forward to a renewed spirit of cooperation in Rondeau in the future.

40053.comment: I support the three-year lease extension as described in ERO Policy Proposal 019-0907, which should be granted automatically to all leaseholders. I support a permanent solution to ensure this cottage community remains in perpetuity with reasonable operating terms and on fair and reasonable financial terms to the cottage owners. I support a permanent solution being implemented as soon as possible.

40054.comment: I support the three-year lease extension as described in ERO Policy Proposal 019-0907. I also support finding a long-term solution to ensure the cottage community remains a viable part of the Chatham Kent community.  Any long-term solution should be on fair and reasonable financial terms to the cottagers.

40055.comment:
RE: 019-0907 the supporting documents offered online were out of date reflecting changes from a decade ago and not the current amendments. That said, the emailed summary of Nov 18, 2019 inviting comments, suggests the proposal is a for a short term 3 year extension of leases so that the ministry may consult on an alternative option for long term occupation of cottage lots.
What is needed is a clear, timely decision that allows for long term planning by all people using and managing movements inside the park. I encourage there to be focused energy, attention and commitment to swiftly resolve the details around lease extension for at least the next 20 years.
I understand that the Ministry seeks the right balance to serve all the communities which migrate to Rondeau on a seasonal and annual basis--whether human, animal, or plant. What I wish for is to be able to erase the enmity that uncertainty and polarization have created. I want turn our energies to constructive, positive interactions that support the needs of all the indigenous and visiting populations to the park.
It's hard to be invested in building or even maintaining properties and relationships when the future is uncertain.
Let's put the delays behind us and put our energies into crafting a future in which all entities touched by the park may collaborate and flourish.

40057.comment: I support the three-year lease extension as described in ERO Policy Proposal 019-0907. This new lease extension should be granted automatically to all leaseholders.  I also support a long-term renewable lease with financial terms tied to a comparable term government of Ontario bond plus a reasonable spread.
